node.title: 8 Picture Books About Food and Fellowship
node.description: From soul food on Sundays and tamales on Christmas Eve to wu gok on Dumpling Day.
node.content: ["TOMATOES FOR NEELAWritten by Padma LakshmiIllustrated by Juana Martinez-Neal", "A twinkly-eyed Indian American girl makes tomato sauce with her amma every summer, when the juicy, plump fruits are in season. Lakshmi\u2019s language infuses the ritual with magic \u2014 a cookbook from the girl\u2019s paati looks \u201cold and important,\u201d as if it\u2019s \u201cfull of spells\u201d \u2014 and Martinez-Neal\u2019s acrylic and colored-pencil illustrations on hand-textured paper conjure the sweet flavors of chutney. The text and art simmer and swirl in sync, from Amma\u2019s cooking dance (\u201cfaster beats\u201d when she shakes spices, her bracelets \u201cclicking and clacking\u201d) to the pungent aromas wafting through the air.", "40 pp. Viking. $17.99. (Ages 3 to 7)", "MAY YOUR LIFE BE DELICIOSAWritten by Michael GenhartIllustrated by Loris Lora", "Each Christmas Eve, a Mexican American girl and her mam\u00e1, t\u00eda, sister and cousins make tamales in her abuela\u2019s kitchen. The recipe is in Abuela\u2019s heart, and the molding and folding of corn husks into nourishing treats is paired with her metaphoric blessings (for flexibility, support, protection and loving hugs). Inspired by midcentury illustration and design, Lora\u2019s cutout, paper-doll-style art matches the 1960s and \u201970s Southern California setting of Genhart\u2019s childhood, where members of his family worked in produce fields and packing houses.", "40 pp. Cameron Kids. $17.99. (Ages 5 to 7)", "DUMPLING DAYWritten by Meera Sriram Illustrated by In\u00e9s de Antu\u00f1anoRecipes by Laurel P. Jackson", "A neighborhood dumpling party brings together 10 families representing 10 cultures (though many of the families are themselves a mix of ethnicities) to share 10 recipes for this savory treat \u2014 which are all basically, though ingredients vary, dough wrapped around a filling. Samosas, wu gok, fufu balls, gyoza, bourekas, tamales, shish barak, pelmeni, ravioli and apple dumplings are all included in this, you guessed it, counting book. While there isn\u2019t much of a story and the rhyme is a bit sing-songy, it provides a solid pre-Thanksgiving introduction to what people eat around the world.", "40 pp. Barefoot Books. $17.99. (Ages 4 to 9)", "FAMILY REUNIONWritten by Chad and Dad RichardsonIllustrated by Ashleigh Corrin", "\u201cNo reunion. NOPE.\u201d This boy won\u2019t go. But go he does, only to find a sea of people he doesn\u2019t know wearing red family-tree T-shirts. \u201cDad shugs, Mom hugs. Not me. NO. Force field activate.\u201d (Corrin draws him inside a bubble, scowling as a relative pokes it with her finger.) Suddenly he notices these \u201cstrangers\u201d look like him. \u201cIs that ME?\u201d Soon he\u2019s having a blast. While the son-father writing team\u2019s debut is uneven, Corrin\u2019s spirited, quirky illustrations save the day.", "24 pp. Barefoot Books. $16.99. (Ages 5 to 10)", "A SONG OF FRUTASWritten by Margarita Engle.Illustrated by Sara Palacios.", "When a young girl visits her grandfather in Cuba, she helps him sell frutas from his cart, singing the names of each one as they walk, while competing pregoneros sing louder to be heard. Happily, camaraderie prevails: \u201cOur voices are bridges that reach up to windows.\u201d The girl\u2019s favorite day is New Year\u2019s Eve, when everyone buys 12 grapes \u2014 one wish for each month, to be gobbled at midnight. Her last wish is friendship between countries, so her abuelo can visit her.", "40 pp. Atheneum. $17.99. (Ages 4 to 8)", "SOUL FOOD SUNDAYWritten by Winsome BinghamIllustrated by C.G. Esperanza", "To capture this sprawling, high-energy extended family gathering, Esperanza\u2019s vibrant, kinetic oil-paint illustrations stretch edge to edge, sometimes tilted to reflect the changing perspectives of people in motion. A boy finally big enough to put on Grandpa\u2019s chef jacket and help Granny make mac \u2019n\u2019 cheese narrates with awe, his excitement palpable: \u201cCheeses stack high like a mountain.\u201d Next Granny fills the sink with water, vinegar and lemon juice. \u201cGreens got to be clean, baby,\u201d she says, the music of Bingham\u2019s conversational poetry rich and real.", "48 pp. Abrams. $17.99. (Ages 4 to 8)", "LET ME FIX YOU A PLATEA Tale of Two KitchensWritten and illustrated by Elizabeth Lilly", "Based on the author\u2019s and her sisters\u2019 experience growing up in Maryland with an American father and a Colombian mother, this tale of a family\u2019s very, very long road trip once a year to visit both sets of tchotchke-loving, food-obsessed grandparents \u2014 one in West Virginia; the other in Florida \u2014 is written and drawn with a refreshingly droll realism, like the best offbeat documentaries. People fall asleep at the table and mostly don\u2019t smile (thank goodness!), but the love they share is evident on every page.", "40 pp. Neal Porter/Holiday House. $18.99. (Ages 4 to 8)", "A FEAST FOR JOSEPHWritten by Terry Farish and OD BonnyIllustrated by Ken Daley", "At the East African refugee camp, aunties stirred kwon at night in the hot wind. Boys played the awal. Now Joseph and Mama live in an apartment and \u201cthere are not enough people to eat with.\u201d The girl upstairs says, \u201cI\u2019m here,\u201d but Joseph waits for others: his abuba across the ocean, his cousins across town. Then one day the girl and her mami pop in with cake. \u201cSlowly a hum settles around them. A rhythm, a beat of people eating together,\u201d even if it\u2019s \u201conly two more.\u201d", "32 pp. Groundwood. $18.99. (Ages 3 to 6)", "Follow New York Times Books on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram, sign up for our newsletter or our literary calendar. And listen to us on the Book Review podcast."]
